body_html:
@apaszke Here is the CPU load when running the same benchmark on the same machine with two separate fresh anaconda+pytorch installs with the latest commit and, respectively, commit @761d679. The screens are captured during the backward phase on CPU.
The latest commit seems to ignore torch.set_num_threads(4) during error backpropagation.
body_text:
@apaszke Here is the CPU load when running the same benchmark on the same machine with two separate fresh anaconda+pytorch installs with the latest commit and, respectively, commit @761d679. The screens are captured during the backward phase on CPU.
The latest commit seems to ignore torch.set_num_threads(4) during error backpropagation.
body:
@apaszke Here is the CPU load when running the same [benchmark](https://github.com/bit-ml/tensor-benchmarks/blob/master/nn_benchmark.py) on the same machine with two separate fresh anaconda+pytorch installs with the latest commit and, respectively, commit @761d679. The screens are captured during the backward phase on CPU.
The latest commit seems to ignore `torch.set_num_threads(4)` during error backpropagation.

![latest](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1908458/23822819/2dcd3f88-065d-11e7-9e17-4a1441b399b1.png)
![761d679](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1908458/23822821/382442ce-065d-11e7-8973-1ee33ac44506.png)
